Description: Tubular bead in glazed composition; elaborate incised decoration consisting of standing male figure holding long bent staff, scorpion and snake; appears like a cylinder seal; amuletic function?; pierced longitudinally for suspension; light turquoise glaze, quite worn; yellowish porous paste.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published in Budge 1893, no.362. For another bead with a representation of scorpion from Naukratis: Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum E.SC.239 (on scorpion amulets: Herrmann et al. 2010, 119, type 68). Budge, E.A. Wallis 1893, Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.270) (phase 3)
Budge 1893b / Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum (no. 362)
